Content: its like having a permissionless system to select your security guards for the day, its great, open to everyone, right?

Content: oh and it costs at least 10x more, might be 100x more

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
on a typical day dPoW does 100 to 120 BTC transactions
veriblock 100,000+ ??? so it seems it is 1000x more transactions (even accounting for lighter weight per tx), it is just a poor design.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I guess the fact that even after 2.5 years, the first real alternative to dPoW is much less efficient (without any debate) and its security level is still remaining to be seen. I would have thought that after all this time, something that was at least equivalent to dPoW might be made, but so far it seems not. And when the BTC txfee kicks in the cost per veriblock tx will go up which will need to be paid by the chains using it, so from an estimated 1% of mining rewards, it goes up with the fee market.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I read somewhere that veriblock "protected" chains dont have to make any code changes and "just" need to allocate some percentage of blockreward to the PoP miners. Is this really true? If so, then it seems there is no protection at all to the altcoin as it wont even be looking at the external reference hashes. I guess it would allow a postmortem analysis of how the 51% attack violated the VBK hashes. Is there any definite answer to whether VBK provides 51% protection and if the altcoin needs to make code changes?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: It cant be that altcoin miners are subsidizing the VBK bitcoin spam in order to not get any 51% protection, as that is what their main claim. Which would mean that the altcoin must make codechanges. So one of those two things must be wrong

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.veriblock.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/PoP-White-Paper.pdf&ved=2ahUKEwjGp7Cjm6zhAhWwwqYKHQm-AHUQFjAAegQIBhAC&usg=AOvVaw047P8-NUCQBbZLcOJBROz-

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: Link to veriblock whitepaper.

Author: Mark81#4505
Content:
'''To determine which blockchain to accept, the score for each block at each index is calculated 
relative to the other block at the same index, and the scores for all blocks on each chain are 
added together: The first PoP publication for either competing block at fork index 0 was at 
index 1 of the illustrated SP blockchain. The red block at fork index 0, R0, is endorsed by three 
PoP publications which occur at index 1 of the SP blockchain, so its score is 3*(1/((1-1+1)*(1-
1+1))) = 300; R0 = 300. The orange block at fork index 0, O0, is endorsed by two PoP
publications which occur at index 1 of the SP blockchain, and one PoP publication at index 2 
in the SP blockchain, so its score is 2*(1/((1-1+1)*(1-1+1))) + 1*(1/((2-1+1)*(2-1+1))) = 225; O0
= 225. Similarly, R1 = 1*(1/((2-2+1)*(2-2+1))) = 100 and O1 = 2*(1/((3-2+1)*(3-2+1))) = 50. The 
last block in any chain never has any proof weight, because no block has come after it to 
contain PoP endorsements for it; R2 = 0 and O2 = 0. Summing these up, the weight of the red 
chain is 300 + 100 = 400, and the weight of the orange chain is 225 + 50 = 275. Since 400 > 
275, the red chain is the more-endorsed blockchain.''' ðŸ˜³

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: Enough complicated to runaway from it.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
From the Veriblock white paper. "SI" is the protected chain, "SP" would be the chain being notarized to (Bitcoin)
```In order for PoP mining transactions to later be used for consensus, they must be stored in the SI blockchain. Additionally, the block headers of the SP blockchain need to be stored in such a way that consensus of the SP blockchain can be tracked without requiring peers to interface with the SP blockchain network. As such, the blocks on a blockchain implementing PoP contain a  special  segment to  hold  the  new SP blockchain  block  headers  since  the  last SI blockchain blockâ€™s included SP headers.```

Author: Shinzo Abe#9369
Content: @jl777c how is it possible to create a system that recycles BTC's energy and hashing at a negligible electricity cost ?

Author: Shinzo Abe#9369
Content: id think that using all that energy has a pretty significant /resource intensive cost

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: sending a transaction into bitcoin is not high energy cost to re-use it's high public network security.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: re-using bitcoin's "store of value" as a utility for security, for another chain, another ecosystem, other ecosystems tha tuse that ecosystem.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: this is what is negligible energy use, the utility / by-product of a secure network being re-used.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
maybe if you bought a plane ticket to new zealand it is expensive, but taking a local magazine for a friend and putting it in your bag - doesn't cost the plane ticket or the flight.   the hand-delivery of the magazine to a friend, piggy backed off the plane ticket.
the commitment to mining bitcoin or taking the flight is a "sunk cost" - equipment wise, environmental wise etc. getting more out of the already incurred expense
